text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new bull album
no mythologies to follow this is the
deluxe debut full-length LP from Danish
singer-songwriter and pianist Karen
Murray Oersted she has come seemingly
out of nowhere with instant electro pop
it's like pilgrim glass off of the
strength of these tracks she got a
pretty quick and very nice endorsement
from Diplo who produced a beat off of
this LP and Karen is showing a ton of
promise so early on in her career I
think she's at a point right now where
she is yet to really chisel out a
distinct or memorable or a unique sound
for herself but I think she has shown a
lot of prowess in the realm of singing
in the realm of hook writing I think
this girl's mystical sound in her vocal
range as long as she continues to do
them well are going to take her far and
earn her fans from people who find her
style to be similar to that of like
Lourdes or Grimes or purity ring or
churches or Nicki in the dove or Glasser
or the knife her music has a really
strong pop appeal but I think her
instrumentals are a little eccentric
there's a ton of atmosphere surrounding
the rhythms and the synthesizers the
beats the the percussion sounds that she
tends to use feel kind of organic a
little primal every once in a while she
switches out these drum sounds in favor
of a sort of 808 drum sound where she
gives a bit of a nod to trap music and
consistently the synthesizers whether it
be the melodies that they're playing or
just the the the tone the the effect the
sound of the sense that she's using have
a bit of a in 80's chart-topping pop hit
vibe occasionally Karen veers from this
formula and sort of ends up in a totally
different genre entirely like on the
song never want to know a song that
feels like a synthetic take on some kind
of vocal pop song from the 1950s or the
song dust is gone which is a bit of an
airy ballad where the way she sings in
the way she pronounces her lyrics on
this track she sounds a lot like Lana
Del Rey or the song don't want to dance
which is like
the most blatantly poppy track on this
entire LP I don't wanna dance with
nobody dance with nobody
oh but with that hook the groove is so
infectious it kind of is a dance song
you know you do want to dance just not
with anybody get away from me or the
song slow love another favor of mine on
this LP which is just like a pop ballad
straight out of the 80s there's there's
nothing really about this track that
feels new at all the synth bass line is
amazing some of the synthesizer leads
feel like something out of a todo song
loving the drum fills on this track too
when the chorus hits I go insane but the
songs that ended up appealing to me the
most on this LP are the ones that sound
most like the singles that led up to the
release of this record like the vocal
layering on the song fire rides is
awesome I love the snappy snares on this
track I love it when Karen reaches up
into her upper register on the song -
she doesn't have the most distinct voice
on the block but I think her singing is
emotive I think it's sensual and I think
in comparison with a lot of these
artists who I find her to be similar to
she shows a little bit more technical
talent she harmonizes over her own
vocals really well and I think she has
great pitch control I love the pan-flute
synthesizer leads on the song red in the
gray as well as the bubbling synthesizer
arpeggios just rhythmically playing into
the tempo of the track
I love the glockenspiel and the Phil
Collins like drum fills as well as the
synthesizer horn leads on the song
pilgrim the song xxx 88 where Diplo
handles the instrumental here the beat
actually complements all the songs on
this record and Caryn really well it
doesn't feel out of place or anything
like that
however the melody and the vocal
harmonies on this track do feel eerily
similar to that of Lords which I guess
isn't that big of a surprise considering
last year's when Royals really blew up
last year's when the song originally
came out and the song glass is really
good as a closer to the sort of normal
non deluxe version of this record with
its really jittery very colourful
instrumental I think Karen has a lot of
great ideas and the hooks are especially
good on this LP but here and there I
think she's a little
too quick to embrace the sound of her
contemporaries also I think there's
maybe a little too much similarity
between how each of the tracks here are
mixed and just how they sound overall
and while I do like a lot of the hooks
on this record I think Karen has a bit
of a weak spot in her songwriting in
that her approach to vocal melody on the
verses of these tracks feels roughly the
same - it's really the synthesizer leads
and the hooks that give each song on
this record their distinct flavor it's
not so much Karen's voice which I mean
sometimes doesn't sound like anything
special sometimes just sounds exactly
like another artist who's already
popular right now and you know those
verses again they're just not that
distinct sometimes don't get me wrong I
think there are a lot of good
characteristics to this record the
rhythms the instrumentation all of its
very tangible all of it is very well
assembled and put together and like I
said consistently I do get into these
hooks I mean there's only really one
track I was just outrightly disappointed
with and that was a song walk this way
which to me the the production the sound
quality of this track was sort of that
of demo however the hook is really good
on this song so I could sort of see why
Karen would want to include it on the
tracklist here but still the recording
quality of the track really does have
this song feeling a little out of place
though you know that this this LP while
there were some bright moments and there
were some tracks on here I really liked
it's just really really hit or miss for
me and that's all I'm kind of feeling a
decent strong six on this thing
transition if you've given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Anthony Fantana well forever
